name: battery separator production | battery separator | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/3746/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg separator, i.e. a polyethylene porous membrane of circa 15-25 µm thickness between a cathode and an anode, for a Li-ion battery. This dataset relies on data from the environmental performance assessment report of a company in China (see Yin et al., 2019), thus it is considered to be representative of this geographical region. Separators can be produced via either wet or dry process. Approximately 80% of the global market of separators use the wet process. In general, the wet process has more advantages, for instance it is a more versatile method which can be used in a wide range of polymers and processing conditions and it can be operated as a continuous process (Deimede et al., 2015).;References:;Yin, R., Hu, S., & Yang, Y. (2019). Life cycle inventories of the commonly used materials for lithium-ion batteries in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 227, 960-971.;Deimede, V., & Elmasides, C. (2015). Separators for lithium‐ion batteries: a review on the production processes and recent developments. Energy technology, 3(5), 453-468.

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process at the factory via lorry.

The activity ends with the production at factory gate of 1kg polyethylene separator via wet process.
category: C:Manufacturing/27:Manufacture of electrical equipment/272:Manufacture of batteries and accumulators/2720:Manufacture of batteries and accumulators

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is from 2017 (year of the publication of data in the environmental performance assessment report) to 2025 (assuming that polyethylene separators produced via wet process are still in use in the near future)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset relies on data from a Chinese company, therefore it is considered representative of the geography China.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The separator separates anode from cathode in a battery cell, still allowing an exchange of lithium ions through micropores. In case of too high process temperature of the battery, the separator melts, thus closes the micopores, and interrupts the lithium ions exchange. In this way the chemical process is stopped and the cell is prevented from overheating or burning. ;;The wet process via which separators are produced involves several steps: (1) mixing of a polyolefin resin e.g. polyethylene with plasticizers or low-molecular-weight substances, such as paraffin oil or wax, (2) melting of the mixture, (3) extruding the mixture into a gel-like film, (4) stretching of the film,  and finally (5) extracting the plasticizer with volatile solvents to form micropores. (Deimede et al., 2015). ;;Reference:;Deimede, V., & Elmasides, C. (2015). Separators for lithium‐ion batteries: a review on the production processes and recent developments. Energy technology, 3(5), 453-468.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
The data about the production process of the separator are retrieved from the literature (Yin et al., 2019 - Table S27, section 2.2.3.1 in the supplementary material). 

Reference:
Yin, R., Hu, S., & Yang, Y. (2019). Life cycle inventories of the commonly used materials for lithium-ion batteries in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 227, 960-971.

exchanges.description: Literature. Table S27 in Yin et al. (2019)
Literature. Table S27 in Yin et al. (2019)

EcoSpold01Location=RER
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. 
References: 
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. 
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.om ecoinvent)
